history.content: I would think so. I took 70 in the summer and it is very fast and difficult to keep up if you do not have prior math experience.

children.subject: But yeah, I kind of agree with the student answer that it would be pretty tough. I took 70 over the summer with another non-CS class and that was already pretty rough, and you may get hit with proj2 in 161 while having to study for your 70 midterm 2 and that will not be pretty.

Keep in mind if you do take this combination, 161 requires 70 as a pre-requisite. There's not a ton of reliance on 70, I would say though if you take them concurrently you may want to read up on RSA, modular arithmetic, and FLT before 161 since it pops up during the cryptography section. You wouldn't need to know it in depth and you may even get away with not knowing these things at all, but there was a question or two during discussion or an exam where I remember them referencing FLT in the answer, and they don't go over this since they assume you took 70. They may use modular arithmetic a couple times in this section as well, and again they won't review it they'll just use it.

<md>
I would recommend taking only one tech and maybe one breadth class (or 2 if you want to take 1 in a different session). But that depends on your past experience. How familiar are you with discrete math and probability (CS70)? How comfortable are you with dealing with CS projects (project 2 in CS161)? How comfortable are you with algorithms in general (cryptography in CS161)? Consider these questions carefully before you make a decision.
</md>

I wouldn't recommend this unless you feel very comfortable with CS70 or CS161 material. CS161 projects will be the same difficulty as a regular fall/spring semester, but with half the time to complete each one. I didn't take it over the summer myself but I can imagine CS70 is equally fast-paced.

By the way, summer CS161 won't require any CS70 as a prerequisite (to address two followups above).

-CS161 summer co-instructor
